awd_titl_txt: Examining the Importance of Dynamic Trafficking in Systemic Acquired Resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants can induce a unique form of systemic resistance termed systemic acquired resistance (SAR), which functions even better than the acquired immunity of vertebrates because it protects against secondary infection from a broad-spectrum of pathogens. During SAR, a mobile signal(s) generated at the site of primary infection, moves systemically presumably through the phloem to prepare the non-infected portions of the plant against future infections. However, our knowledge of the intercellular transport of the SAR signal(s) is limited. The investigators have identified several key components of the mobile SAR signal(s) and associated them with specific biochemical signaling pathways responsible for inducing SAR. In this project the investigators will study how these signals are transported during SAR and identify the components involved in their transport. 

Although the phloem is the presumed site of signal translocation, little has been done to determine the mechanism of intercellular transport of the SAR inducing signal(s). Potentially, the identification of SAR signal(s) and the knowledge of their dynamic movement could facilitate the use of SAR in protecting agriculturally important plants against a wide range of pathogens. This project will examine the role of dynamic gating (opening and closing) of the plasmodesmata (PD) in SAR induction and assess its relationship to some essential mobile SAR inducers. PD gating will be assessed using dye-loading assays during the time frame of SAR signal generation and movement. Molecular and genetic tools will be used to alter PD gating within this time frame and assess the effect on SAR. Metabolome analysis of petiole exudates from plants defective in both SAR and PD gating will be carried out to determine levels of known SAR inducers and to identify other unknown SAR regulators. Molecular, genetic, and biochemical analyses will be used to characterize the relationship between PD and various SAR related components.  The knowledge gained through this project will facilitate the use of SAR in developing long lasting and broad-spectrum crop protection strategies. Regulation of metabolite transport is fundamental to all aspects of plant development because it affects the movement of metabolites and signaling molecules between cells and across organs. Therefore, this project would provide conceptual advances relevant to both health and disease physiologies of plants. The significant similarity of symplasmic structures in animals and plants extends the relevance of this work to animal physiology. This project will involve training of undergraduate students from local colleges, which in turn will facilitate a partnership between the University of Kentucky and primarily minority and/or underrepresented student-serving institutions in the state. The investigators' involvement in STEM education will generate research opportunities for middle/high school students in the state. This project will also involve the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Data generated from this project will be available via a project-specific website as well as traditional routes including publications and presentations.

por.por_cntn:
Plants possess a unique form of immunity called systemic acquired resistance (SAR). SAR is highly desirable because it protects the whole plant against a wide range of pathogens and is long-lasting. Studies show that plants can also alert neighboring plants once SAR is activated. When a plant first encourters pathogen infection, it can activate the generation of signals at the infection site. Some of these siganls are mobile and can travel to distal portions of the plant, and prepare the entire plant to fend off any future infections. Understanding the processes underlying SAR are important for harnessing this powerful mechanism in agriculture and environmental applications. This project examined how some of the key SAR signals are transported cell-to-cell. In particular, this project examined the importance of plasmodesmata (cytoplasmic connections between neighboring cells) and their dynamic opening and closing in the transport of key SAR signals and SAR activation.

The following major discoveries were made:

1)     The transport routes of three key mobile inducers of SAR were identified. These include glycerol-3-phosphate (G3P, phosphorylated sugar derivative), azelaic acid (AzA, dicarboxylic acid), and salicylic acid (SA, plant hormone).

2)     G3P and AzA were discovered to preferentially move through the plasmodesmata. Proteins that are located at the plasmodesmata and regulate its opening and closing through callose (glucose based polysaccharide) deposition were found to be key to this process.

3)     The long-standing notion that systemic movement of SA is not essential for SAR was discounted and SAR transport was shown to be essential for SAR activation.

4)     Unlike G3P and AzA, SA does not move cell-to-cell intracellularly. Rather, SA prefers to move primarily through the apoplast (space between the plasma membrane and cell wall). This is governed by the water usage efficiency and transpiration in the plant.

5)     A portion of the cellular SA was discovered to be partitioned to the plant cuticle (waxy layer that surrounds all aerial parts of the plant). The integrity of the cuticle was found to be crucial for proper SA transport and SAR activation.

6)     A novel systemically mobile signal of SAR was identified. This signal, a small RNA molecule, is one of the earliest signals generated upon SAR activation.

7)     Some of the mobile SAR signals were found to help the plant discern between poor and efficient nitrogen fixing rhizobacteria, thus impacting nitrogen availability in the plant.

 

Overall this project generated new knowledge that enables harnessing the powerful features of SAR for mitigating crop diseases as well as addressing the environmental impacts of plant pests. The findings directly benefit US agriculture because they relate to discoveries made in the major US crop soybean. This project resulted in the professional training of numerous postdoctoral scholars and graduate students, and generated research training opportunities for undergraduate and high school students. Additionally, the project included science-related outreach activities such as plant biology workshops at the Lexington Youth Science Summit (middle/high school students), Girl Scouts GEMS program (middle/high school girl scouts), Fayette county Family Science Night (elementary/middle school students and their families) and the Limitless Leaders conference (middle and high school girls of minority backgrounds). The research findings made through this project were publicly disseminated via scientific publications, presentations at national and international conferences, and presentations to state grain crop growers.
